description.narrative:
Corruption in Kenya is endemic and permeates all sectors of society. Corruption is a major hindrance for development and increased transparency and demand for accountability is one way to prevent corruption. In the Global Corruption Perception Index 2014 Kenya was ranked 145 out of 177 countries surveyed. The Global Corruption Barometer (GCB) for 2013 show that 7 out of every 10 Kenyans are of the opinion that corruption is a problem in public service. A similar proportion believes that in order to get anything done in public sector you have to have personal contacts at a particular service delivery institution. Furthermore, one third of the population states that corruption has increased a lot during the last two years.
The overall objective of the proposed intervention is to contribute to strengthened democratic accountability and transparency in Kenya through citizen monitoring of government expenditure, in order to uncover suspected corruption and mismanagement of public funds. Fojo has proposed to do this through the development and implementation a set of secure tools and methodologies for carrying out citizen monitoring of Kenyan government budgeting and expenditure. Journalists, community leaders, civil society activists and local civil servants will be empowered to monitor government funds and report suspected mismanagement in public administration, in order to defend their human rights to education and health care.
Fojo and its partners will develop an ICT platform that will provide easily understood information about how much public funds have been allocated to each school and health centre in an area. Using a mobile phone with internet access, anyone will be able to check the amount of government money pledged to each school or health clinic as well as the amount actually spent. The same application can be used from any computer. So, if a person living in Kenya wants to check how much money the government is supposed to be spending on the school that his/her children is attending, they can download the app or go on the website and click on the actual school to see the sum officially budgeted for as well as get access to information about the school, such as how many teachers that should be working there or that there is how many books is budgeted for each pupil. The platform also gives the possibility to anonymously and securely report on suspected mismanagement. For people without internet access it will be possible to report using sms or calling a toll-free number. All whistle blowing reports will be published on the programme’s Facebook page. This provides the possibility for journalists, civil society activists, civil servants and citizens to discuss their personal findings, share information and experiences, reporting suspected corruption. The proposed programme will be implemented in Embakasi with is the Eastern part of Nairobi County. It is mainly a residential area for lower middle income households.

Korruption genomsyrar alla samhällssektorer i Kenya och är ett huvudsakligt hinder för utvecklingen. Ökad insyn och ansvarsutkrävande är ett sätt att förebygga korruption. I Transparency International (TI) Corruption Perception Index 2014 rankades Kenya på 145 plats av 174 undersökta länder, och i Global Corruption Barometer (GCB) för 2013 visar att 7 av 10 kenyaner anser att korruption är ett problem i den offentliga sektorn. En lika stor andel anser att det krävs personliga kontakter för att få tillgång till offentliga tjänster. Var tredje kenyan anser vidare att korruptionen i landet har ökat betydligt under de två senaste åren.
Det övergripande målet för Action for Transparency programmet (A4T) är att bidra till stärkt ansvarsskyldighet och insyn i användandet av offentliga medel genom medborgardelaktighet. Fojo och deras samarbetspartners kommer att utveckla en rad verktyg och metoder för att upptäcka misstänkt korruption och misskötsel av offentliga medel. A4T programmet kommer att utveckla en ICT-plattform som kommer att tillhandahålla lättförstådd information om hur mycket offentliga medel har anslagits till varje skola och vårdcentral i ett område. Med hjälp av en mobiltelefon med internetuppkoppling eller dator kommer vem som helst att kunna kontrollera mängden statliga medel som allokerats till varje skola och vårdcentral, samt det belopp som faktiskt spenderats.
Om en person vill få upplysningar om hur mycket pengar kommunen har budgeterat för den skola där hennes/ hans barn går, kan de ladda ner appen eller gå till A4Ts hemsida och klicka på den aktuella skolan för att få veta detta. Vidare kommer de även kunna få information om till exempel hur många lärare som ska arbeta där eller hur många böcker har budgeterats för varje elev. Plattformen kommer också ge möjlighet att anonymt och säkert rapportera om misstänkt misskötsel och korruption. För de personer som inte har tillgång till internet är det möjligt att rapportera detta genom att använda sms eller ringa ett gratisnummer. Alla dessa whistleblowingrapporter kommer att publiceras på programmets Facebooksida. Detta ger möjlighet för journalister, aktivister, tjänstemän och medborgare att dela information samt att diskutera sina egna personliga iakttagelser och erfarenheter.
I denna fas kommer programmet att genomföras i Embakasi, som är ett bostadsområde för lägre medelinkomsttagare i den östra delen av Nairobi County.

description.narrative: The project was recently and ambitiously evaluated in Samuel Otieno, “A4T Endline evaluation report” (Brandmetrics Africa Ltd, 2020). Sida was not involved in this evaluation. The evaluators conclude that the project was relevant. Corruption is an serious problem in the education and health sectors in Nairobi County, the training and workshops were useful, journalists and their mentors as well as “A4T advocates” found the project useful, and the A4T app and platforms for reporting suspected corruption were useful, although there was concern about out-of-date budget information and a lack of follow-up on reported corruption (pp. 10-16). The evaluators found the project efficient. 33 project activities were planned and executed reaching 4,891 people, including public awareness and outreach activities, stakeholder engagements and training/workshops. Other activities included partnership engagements, software development and online engagements, which also indirectly had people interacting with the project. The project reached both genders across most activities. The project targeted a wide range of critical stakeholders such as Boards of Management at public schools, community and religious leaders, health management committees and “A4T advocates” (pp. 16-17). Regarding effectiveness, the evaluators found that the project met most beneficiaries’ expectation, mentored journalists were particularly pleased. Training participants were mostly like to use the A4T app or Facebook page, although again there were concerns about outdated information and the absence of follow-up. Looking at the impact of A4T, *The evaluators stated, “There is strong evidence that the project has succeed in creating awareness on issues to do transparency and accountability in public funds management among the community leaders and opinion shapers. In particular, the A4T app….” (p. 21). In the qualitative interviews, “… Most respondents said the project had contributed immensely in improving knowledge on corruption and accountability particularly in the public education and health sector through the trainings for various community stakeholders” (p. 22). *“The project had increased the capacity of beneficiaries in counteracting corruption in their communities. Not only do they feel that the training was useful in building their capacity to do their community roles but actually motivated them to carry our various activities that support the aims of the project (pp. 22-23). *“There is evidence that the project has contributed in improving the quality of journalism through the journalist training and mentorships project. It can be said that the improvement in journalism has happened at three levels; individual journalists’ skills, increased coverage of stories and motivation to cover important issues” (p. 29). *“There is strong evidence to indicate that the project had made beneficiaries active in community processes and interactions” (pp. 31-33). *Finally, the is evidence of the project influencing election outcomes, public land issues, t4he Office of the Auditor General, and monitoring the use of COVID-19 funds (pp. 35-37).
